Tunc ostendere restat
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 20, c. 1, n. 1
. This is distinction 20 in which after the Master shows the equality of persons with respect to the magnitude of perfection in their being, here he shows the same thing with respect to power in acting.

And it is divided into two parts because first he shows the equal power of the divine persons, in the second place from what has been said in introduces and incidental difficulty. The second begins in the beginning of distinction 21
hic oritur quaestio
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 21, c. 1, n. 1
.

The first part is divided into two because in the first place the Master proves what he has proposed by authority, the second by reason, which begins at
Item alio modo
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 20, c. 3, n. 4
.

The second principal part, which is distinction 21, is divided into two because first the Master introduces a debatable question, in the second place he introduces a general rule that should be observed regarding such questions. The second begins at
verum tamen ut ait Augustinus
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 21, c. 3, n. 3
.

Distinction 22 follows at
post praedicta disserendum
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 22, c. 1, n. 1
in which the Master, after he determined about those things which are intrinsic, here he treats the names expressing its intrinsic perfections, like vo?lia names. And this part is divided into two because first he shows the double order regarding the names of it, in the second place he puts a
useful rule. The second begins at
sciendum ergo
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 22, c. 4, n. 1
. And this is the division and opinion of this distinction in general.
Whether any divine supposite on account of its own equal power is equally able to make the something contingent exists.

That not because among the divine supposites there is not equality properly speaking nor the highest equality, therefore they do not have equal power. The antecedent is proved first because equality properly said is not able to found except among moveable magnitudes. In the second place because quality of the divine supposites is not and does not assert something positive, as appears to be the opinion of the
Master sentire in distinction 23, chapter 2
Lomardus, Sent. I, d. 23, c. 2, xxx
. And again because such equality would be a real relation or a relation of reason, but neither of these is said, therefore.

In the second place, if this were true, it follows that the Son and the Holy Spirit have the power of producing the Son. The consequent is false. The consequence is clear since the Father has this power and de facto alone produces the Son

In the third place, the Father alone is God, therefore the Father alone is omnipotent, therefore the Father alone has the power of producing every possibile thing, therefore the Son and the Holy Spirit are able to produce nothing in any more or to making anything exist. The consequences are known, and the antecedent is proved because the Father alone is God which antecedent should have proved.

In opposition, it is argued through the
Master in these distinctions
Lombardus, Sent. I, dd. xxx
. Again,
Augustine, in De fide ad Petrum , says
none of the three divine persons precedes the other in eternity or exceeds it in magnitude or surpasses it in power
Ps-Augustinus, De fide ad Petrum
, therefore.

The first conclusion: though everything with respect to moveable quantity is repugnant to every divine supposite, nevertheless the divine supposites are equal in the highest degree understanding equality in the proper sense. The first part is clear through
Blessed Augustine, V De Trinitate, in chapter one
where he says
we understand God inasmuch as we are able to be great without quantity, good without quality
Augustinus, De Trinitate V, 1, 2
etc. The second part is proved because every proposition, if it is through regarding the property of the word, is true. But this is true, the divine persons are equal or equality is in the divine persons, therefore properly and not improperly. This part is proved by Scotus and Landulphus, the arguments for which are stated by
Alphonsus, in book one, distinction 19, question 2, article 2, conclusion 1
Vargas, Sent. I, d. 19, q. 2, a. 2, concl. 1
who works to resolve them, and he holds the opposing position and proves it in thee same place.

First corollary: though the same thing is the equality of perfection among the divine persons, nevertheless between them there is a true likeness properly speaking. This is clear through the conclusion. It is confirmed because where there is greater perfection, equality and likeness are truer and more proper. But among the divine supposites there is equality and likeness, therefore it is most proper and most true.

Second corollary: a divine is compared to another only and similarly because, if one of them were shown clearly to a creature and it was not prescinded from its origin or emanation, then no distinction between them would be posited by the one seeing. This is clear because every distinction in the divine is founded upon the origins and emanations of the persons according to
Damascenum Ioannes Damascenus, xxx .

Third corollary: it is not the case that the created intellect conceives the equality of the divine supposites and at the very same time grasps the same essence and perfectional magnitude. This is clear through
Augustine, V De Trinitate, in chapter 7 , where he says
we ask according to what is the Son equal to the Father; not according to what is to the Father si the Son said to be equal to the Father. Therefore it remains that it is said to be equal according to that which is to itself
Augustinus, De Trinitate V, 6, 7 (xxx)
, and therefore it is inferred that the substance is equal. And after these words the Master concludes, therefore he says
the equality of the Father and the Son is not a notion but a unity of nature.
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 31, c. 3, [n. 6]

From this it seems to follows in the first place that the equality and likeness are not said in the divine only privatively, but really and positively because the Son is equal to othe Father according to his substance, as Augustine says. Again, if they were not differing positively, then the equal divine persons would not differ than non entities and impossibiles. The consequence holds because a chimera is not greater or lesser than a unicorn,
if therefore such remotion suffices for equality, then the inferred consequent follows.

Second conclusion: though it is necessary that the Father alone produces something omnipotent, nevertheless only the Father is able to produce anything contingent or to conserve it in being. The first is clear because only the Father in the divine produces the omnipotent Son necessarily, as was clear above. The second part is proved because it follows that only the Father produces something contingent, therefore the Son does not produces what is contingent. But outside the works of the Trinity are undivided. The consequence is clear through explaining in an exclusive way.

The first corollary: though the Son has the power of generating from the Father, nevertheless the Son is not internally able to produce himself the Son nor another. The first part is clear because the power of generating the Son falls under omnipotence, but the Son is omnipotent, therefore. The second is clear because, if he were able to produce the Son, then de facto he would have done so from eternity, and thus there would be a quaternity of persons in the divine, which is false.

Second corollary: to be something omnipotence does not imply the power itself to produce everything producibile. This is clear because the Son in the divine is producibile, and nevertheless the same Son is not able to produce itself, therefore, even though it is omnipotent.

Third corollary: that no one explains divine omnipotence sufficiently through the power to make whatever exists or or cause something that does not imply a contradiction. This is clear because in the divine the essence is and nevertheless no one is able to make it, therefore.

Third conclusion: though it is necessary that every divine supposite is equally omnipotent, [nevertheless] it is not the case that only one divine supposite is God. The first is clear because
the omnipotent Father, the omnipotent Son Quicumque Vult , etc. The second is proved because it follows that only the Father is God, therefore the Son is not God. The consequent is impossible, but the consequence is clear because an exclusive saying, taken purely exclusively, added to one of the related things, excludes the other, as is clear through deduction of the
Philosopher I Physics
making a similar consequence, saying
only the beginning is, then what is from the beginning is not
Aristotle, Physics, I, 2 185a305
This is confirmed because only the Father is God, therefore nothing else from the Father is God The consequences is clear from from the one explaining to the explained. The consequent is false because the Son, which is something else from the Father is God, and similarly the Holy Spirit is God.

First corollary: though every merely exclusive proposition, whose predicate suits any of its correlatives, is false, nevertheless every proposition, whose predicate is able to suit one of its correlatives without the other, is true. An example of the first, this is false, only the father is because to be suits not only the Father, but any of the three supposites which is proved because it follows only the Father is, therefore the Father is and it follows the Son is not, therefore the Father is not which is the opposite, etc. An example of the second, only the Father generates. This is true because the predicate does not suit the Son or the Holy Spirit and thus those propositions expressing it are true because the Father generates within the divine, and nothing other besides him, therefore alone.

Second corollary: the application or apposition of a saying exclusive to one of the relative things is an implication or inference of a formal or virtual contradiction. This is clear from the propositions about which the first part of the first corollary speaks, as it was deduced there.

Third corollary: though it is not true that only the Father is God exclusively, nevertheless only the Father is God in the most precise way. The first is clear through what has been said. The second is clear Father as taken precisely with nothing added to it is true God from which follows the affirmative part of the conclusion.

Against the first conclusion, in the divine there this and that quantity, therefore neither is there a quantity properly said. The consequence is clear because equality properly said is the disposition of one quantity to another. The antecedent is clear through
Augustine, V De Trinitate in chapter 10 , who says just
we do not say three essences but one, so we not say three magnitudes but one
Augustinus, De Trinitate, V, 10, 11
.

In the second place against the first corollary, either this likeness is a distinct thing from the identity or it is precisely the same thing. It is not the first because then there would be some distinction in the divine which is greater than the personal distinction. The consequent is false. Nor is it the second because according to Scotus the foundations of such relations are not the same from the nature of the thing, for the essence founds the identity, infinity founds equality, and wisdom founds likeness, but these things are distinguished from the nature of the thing, as is held by ut tenet
Scotus
in distinction 19 of book I, in question 12, in distinction 13
Scotus, Sent. I, d. 19, q. 12

In the third place against the third corollary, complete being of equality dependent on the intellect, therefore it is not a real relation but a relation of reason. The consequence is clear, and the antecedent is proved because the Father is not able to be conceived as equal to the Son unless the same magnitude is accepted twice by the intellect at once in the Father and in the Son

In the fourth place, a real relation requires real extremes that are really distinct, but the same thing is not able to really distinct from itself,, therefore the equality of the divine supposites is not a real relation, but only a relation of reason. The consequence is clear since reality and identity are the same.

Against the second conclusion, omnipotence is possible in everything which is the terminus of active power, according to which this is able to be produced. But the Son in no mode is capable of initial generation, therefore the Son either is not omnipotent or the generation of the Son is not the terminus of active potency.

In the second place against the first and second corollaries, the Father is able to produce the Son and the Son is not able to produce the Father, therefore the Son is not as extensively productively powerful as the Father, therefore.

In the third place against the first part of the first corollary, if the Son were to have the power of producing the Son, it would follow that this production would be able to be reduced to act. The consequent is false through the second part because the Son is not able to generate the Son. And the consequence is clear because a potency which is not able to be reduced to act would be useless, but the potency in the Son is not useless, therefore.

Against the third conclusion, the Father is not able to be separated fromthe Son in being, nor the converse, therefore the exclusive saying added to the Father does not exclude the Son. The consequence holds because an exclusive saying neither removes nor excludes one from the other if those things are not able to be excluded from one another in being and be separated.

In the second place, the greater the connection between the two correlatives than between the entire whole and its parts, but the exclusive saying added to the whole does not exclude the part, therefore what has been added to one of the relatives does not exclude the other. The major premise is known because the posited relatives posit themselves and having been destroyed permeate themselves. The minor is clear because the house alone does not follow therefore it is not equal, rather the opposite follows.
In the third place, if the Father alone is, the Father is, but if the Father is the Son, therefore the exclusive saying does not exclude the correlative

In the fourth place, one of the relatives is from the intellect of the other, therefore it follows that one is not able to be excluded from the other. The consequence is clear because, just as it does not follows that man alone is, animal is not because animal is from the intellect of man and is necessarily included in man, just as the superior includes within itself the inferior, so in what is proposed.

In the fifth place, it is argued with the authority of
Augustine Contra Maximinum, libro 3, capitulo 13
Augustinus, Contra Maximinum, III, c. 13
, where he says, if it were said about the Father alone that he is wise and God is not, nevertheless the Son and Holy Spirit would be excluded because these three are one and they are inseparable.

To the first, the consequence is denied. In the second place, I say that those denying true and proper equality in the divine, consequently have to deny active generation because this follows. In the third place, I say that Augustine in the proof of the consequent receives the abstract through the concrete, and thus equality will still be int he divine properly speaking, for though there are not three magnitudes, nevertheless there are three great things adjectively taken.

To the second, it is said that equality and likeness are not absolutely an identity, but there is an identity of the three persons. And when it is said that not because the foundations of such things are distinguished, this is denied.

To the third, Alphonsus would deny what has been assumed for the proof, because the Father is not able to be grasped, etc He denies this because, as he says, the equality is not other than the identity. But if the response were valid the divine identity would be able to be said to be equal to itself. Therefore I would say differently that the antecedent is true because it does not seem to be well thought that the equality in the divine is grasped unless two essences are received. But it does not follows that the Father is not able to be grasped as equal to the Son
unless the essence is grasped twice by the intellect, therefore the Father is not able to be equal to the Son unless the essence is taken twice because it is the case that it is thus and that no created intellect grasps it thus.

To the fourth, it is said that equality in the divine has sufficiently distinct extremes because I do not say that identity and equality are the absolutely the same as Alphonsus. But I say that equality is the identity of many distinct things and this suffices for the foundation of such relations in the divine

To the first against the second conclusion, I say that Scotus who makes this argument, takes for the same thing to generate and to be able to generate and the power of generating which those who hold the opposite do not have to do. In the second place, it is able to be said that he proves to be held nominally and verbally, but Scotus and all the others standing with take it for the same thing, therefore the argument does not conclude that

To the second, the consequence is denied because the Father just as much as the Son are productive of an infinity of things. In the second place, I say that to not produce the Son is a perfection not an imperfection, therefore the consequence is also not valid.

To the third, the consequence is denied, and to the proof it is conceded as true where the power de facto is not reduct to act or where one having this power is not the terminus reduced through this power to perfect act. But in the proposed, the Son, who has this power, is the terminus reduced to act, therefore the authority of the Philosopher does not conclude.
To the first against the third conclusion, the consequence is denied.

To the second, the major premise is denied universally because the integral part intrisically considers the constitution of the whole, but one of the related does consider instrinsically to the constitution of the other.

To the third, the conditional or consequence is able to be denied because an exclusive saying has been added.
A relation knows the nature of a separating saying, whence just it does not follows that man is dead, therefore man is, so it does not follows that only the Father is, therefore the Father is. In the second place, it is able to be said that that the Father is when the Father is not, especially in creatures.

To the fourth, the consequence is denied because, though one relative is from the intellect secondarily or implied in what is the signified of the other, nevertheless it is not from the intellect or what is principally signified.

To the fifth, it is said that Augustine in such places does not intend this proposition properly, and according to the force of the word it should be conceded, only the Father is God or wise, if only is taken exclusively. But he intends to say that when these propositions are found in scripture, it ought not to be understood that, if an exclusive saying is added to one person, scripture intends to exclude the others because then these authorities would be false by virtue of the fact that the divine persons are one. For sometimes scripture uses these propositions on account of the brevity of the word, supposing that it will be understood about all what is said about only one. And other times he uses these propositions, when taking the exclusive sayings non-exclusively but precisely, and then such propositions are conceded, as it has been said.
To the first argument in the opposition, it is clear what should be said from the first conclusion and corollary.

To the second, it is clear from the second conclusion because, if power or potency are taken nominally or entitatively, thus it is conceded, but if it is taken verbally and executively, then the consequence is denied. And to the proof, because the Father has this power, I say that this power is not something but to something. In the second place, I say that if this gerundive generating is the gerundive of an active verb, then only it is only in the Father, if it is of a passive verb, then it is only in the Son, if an impersonal verbi, then it is any divine supposite.

To the third, it is clear from the conclusion that the antecedent should be denied. And to the proof, the consequence is denied because this is not its converse, but it ought to be converted thus, only God is Father, that is, every Father or every persona of the Father in the divine is God, and this should be conceded as true.

Nunc restat
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 20, c. 1, n. 1
.
First conclusion: that, just as one of the three divine persons is magnitude, so one of the persons is power.

Second conclusion: that the Father is not more powerful than the Son or Holy Spirit nor is one person more powerful than another nor is the Father and Son together more able that the Holy Spirit alone nor are the three together more able than any single one of them.
Third conclusion: that the omnipotence which the Father has the Son accepts by being born and the Holy Spirit accepts by proceeding.

Fourth conclusion: that therefore the Father is not greater than the Son because he was begotten as an equal, whence when it is said the Son is begotten from the Father, this does not show inequality of substance, but the order of nature, not that the one is prior to the other, but by what one is from the other, against Scotus.

Hic oritur quaestio
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 21, c. 1, n. 1
. First conclusion of distinction 22: that when it is said, only the Father, it ought not to be understood that he is without the Son and the Holy Spirit, but by this expression the Son and the Holy Spirit are excluded from the association with paternity or plurality of the Father in the divine is removed.

The second conclusion: that when it is said, only the Son or only the Holy Spirit, the Son is not divided from the Holy Spirit or from the Father nor is the Holy Spirit divided from either, rather the Father and the Holy Spirit are excluded from association with the filial property and the Father and the Son are excluded from association with the processial property

Third conclusion: that though it is properly said, only the Father is the Father and only the Son is the Son, nevertheless it is not said, only the Son is God or only the Father is God, nor the converse, only God is the Son, and similarly about Father et Holy Spirit.
Fourth conclusion: The Father, Son, and Holy Spirit are only one God, and conversely only one God is the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, and the whole Trinity is only one God.

Fifth conclusion: that when we say, the Trinity is alone one God, we do not intend that it is not with holy spirits and souls, but we say only that the Trinity is not other than God, for these with this are not God.

Sixth conclusion: that when one divine person is named, the others are understood, whence, when it is said,
no one knows the Father except the Son
Matthew 11:27 , the Father is not separated and the Holy Spirit is not separated because they are inseparable. Note that no one, that is that no man, and thus this is true when taken exceptively because no other man besides the Son knows the Father with comprehensive knowledge

Post praedictam
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 22, c. ?
etc. First conclusion of distinction 22: that the many names which are said about are different. For some are notional or signifying a property of the persons, like generation, Father, Word, and similar things. Some are essential, like virtue, wisdom, goodness, which are said individually about each person. Some are said translatively or through a likeness, like mirror, splendor, character. Some are said from time in relation to creatures of which some are said of all persons, like lord, creator, etc, and some not about all persons, like gift. Some are some from time, but not relatively to a creature, like incarnate, humane though they include a relation to creature according to reality. Another is the name which is said about all at the same time and not of any individually, like the Trinity.
The second conclusion: that names which properly pertain to individual persons, like Father and Son and Holy Spirit, are said relatively to one another, not substantially.

Third conclusion: that those names which signify the unity of essence are said absolutely and substantially and about all persons individually and about all persons joined together in a singular number not as a plurality, like good, great. For we do not say three goods or three gods, but one when taking the term substantively, but when taking it adjectively they are able to be called three great things.

The fourth conclusion: that
names which are imposed with personal properties are not imposed substantially but relatively.
